#Text=Study suggests ' sleeping sickness ' parasite mutated to evade immune system defences
#Text=Wednesday , September 1 , 2010
#Text=File photo of trypanosoma brucei
#Text=Research teams from the universities of Georgia and Glasgow discovered the mechanism the Trypanosome parasite evolved for " sleeping sickness " disease to circumvent the human immune system .

column1: #Text=Their study follows a recent African outbreak of the disease this parasite causes .
#Text=The discovery is expected to help develop a cure preventing future deaths .
#Text=A tsetse fly , generally responsible for the spread of the condition .
#Text=The 1998 – 2001 sleeping sickness epidemics in South Sudan , Angola , Democratic Republic of Congo , and Uganda caused tens of thousands of deaths .
#Text=The parasites are spread by tsetse flies .
#Text=It is considered one of the worst epidemics in the last five decades .
#Text=As WHO reported , subsequent recent introduction of population screening in rural areas and distribution of more effective drugs had potentially reduced the number of death incidents .
#Text=However , the main effect of these measures being a decrease in spreading of the parasite and not in decrease of the death rate , the researchers decided to tackle the puzzle .
#Text=The scientists studied the molecules the human immune system activates in response to the attack .
#Text=They were looking for the way the parasites inhibit it and lead to the death of the victim .
#Text=Of the several known parasite species , the two that can infect humans were chosen to study , called Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and Trypanosoma brucei rhodensiense .
#Text=Several others also exist , but they affect only animals .
#Text=Researchers knew that the Trypanosoma attacks typically are repelled by an HDL , more specifically trypanosome lytic factor-1 ( TLF-1 ) .
#Text=It is generated in the humans ' immune system and is toxic to the parasites but not to humans .
#Text=It was known that one of the parasites , T. b. rhodensiense , has evolved an inhibitor of the toxic chemical , called Serum Resistance Associated ( SRA ) protein .
#Text=However the other one , T. b. gambiense , was responsible for over 95 % of human deaths , and it had been previously unknown why .
#Text=The study showed that a gene mutation has lead to a change in the parasite 's surface protein receptor .
#Text=It does n't bind to TLF-1 as well as for other species , leading to a substantial decrease in TLF-1 uptake by the parasite .
#Text=The receptor is more strict , causing a lower nutrient intake as well , but it suffices , and the parasite defends against the human immune system .

#Text=As professor and head of the department of biochemistry and molecular biology at UGA ( and one of the leaders of the research ) Stephen Hajduk explained , " Humans have evolved TLF-1 as a highly specific toxin against African trypanosomes by tricking the parasite into taking up this HDL because it resembles a nutrient the parasite needs for survival .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Based on the results of the research , humans could possibly develop a defense mechanism to keep the parasites from evading the human defense system .

#Text=Stephen Hajduk commented ,  We believe this research represents a paradigm shift and causes us to think more broadly about how pathogens avoid host defense mechanisms .
